The last time anyone was on the Moon was during the Apollo 17 mission, which took place in December 1972. This was the sixth and most recent human visit to the lunar surface (Moon landing).

Moon landing A Moon landing is the arrival of a spacecraft on the surface of the Moon. This includes both manned and unmanned (robotic) missions. The first human-made object to reach the surface of the Moon was the Soviet Union's Luna 2 mission, on 13 September 1959. The United States' Apollo 11 was the first manned mission to land on the Moon, on 20 July 1969. There have been six manned U.S. landings (between 1969 and 1972) and numerous unmanned landings, with no soft landings happening from 22 August 1976 until 14 December 2013. Crewed exploration of the Moon began in 1968 with the Apollo 8 mission that successfully orbited the Moon, the first time any extraterrestrial object was orbited by humans. In 1969, the Apollo 11 mission marked the first time humans set foot upon another world. Crewed exploration of the Moon did not continue for long, however. The Apollo 17 mission in 1972 marked the sixth landing and the most recent human visit there, and the next, Exploration Mission 2, is due to orbit the Moon in 2023. the only country to have successfully conducted manned missions to the Moon, with the last departing the lunar surface in December 1972. The Isle of Wight became an island due to rising sea levels that separated it from the mainland. This geographical change occurred around 8,500 years ago, during the Mesolithic period, when the melting glaciers caused the land bridge that connected it to the mainland to be submerged (as referenced in the context of the Isle of Man). The Isle of Wight has been for some purposes in the past treated traditionally part of Hampshire, but has been administered separately from Hampshire for over a century, obtaining a county council of its own in 1890. The Isle of Wight became a full ceremonial county in 1974. The island is excluded from the hundreds given above – it was traditionally divided into East Medina and

are retained in the county archaeological centre. From about 685-686 the island can be considered part of Wessex, and after the West Saxon kings ruled all England, then part of England. The Anglo Saxon Chronicle tells how "Wiht-land" suffered from Viking raids: ""And then another time they lay in the Isle of Wight, and meanwhile ate out of Hampshire and of Sussex"". Alfred the Great's navy defeated the Danes in 871 after they had "ravaged Devon and the Isle of Wight". Around 900 the kingdom was divided into shires, and the island became part of the shire of Hampshire. During

The Isle of Man effectively became an island around 8,500 years ago at around the time when rising sea levels caused by the melting glaciers cut Mesolithic Britain off from continental Europe for the last time. A land bridge had earlier existed between the Isle of Man and Cumbria, but the location and opening of the land bridge remain poorly understood. The ruler of England in 1616 was King James I. He reigned from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625. James I was the first monarch of the House of Stuart and was also known for uniting the crowns of England and Scotland.

Edward VI of England Edward VI (12 October 1537 – 6 July 1553) was King of England and Ireland from 28 January 1547 until his death. He was crowned on 20 February at the age of nine. Edward was the son of Henry VIII and Jane Seymour, and England's first monarch to be raised as a Protestant. During his reign, the realm was governed by a regency council because he never reached his majority. The council was first led by his uncle Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset (1547–1549), and then by John Dudley, 1st Earl of Warwick (1550–1553), from

of Queen Elizabeth I in 1601. He was High Sheriff of Hampshire in 1603 and again in 1629, and High Sheriff of Shropshire in between February and November 1606. He was elected MP for Stockbridge in 1614, (although the election was subsequently voided), and was one of the council for the marches of Wales in 1617. In 1621 he was re-elected for Hampshire and in 1623 he was elected MP for Whitchurch. In 1624 became Custos Rotulorum of Hampshire, a post he held until his death. Charles I of England Charles I (19 November 1600 – 30 January 1649) was the monarch over the three kingdoms of England, Scotland, and Ireland from 27 March 1625 until his execution in 1649. Charles was born into the House of Stuart as the second son of King James VI of Scotland, but after his father inherited the English throne in 1603, he moved to England, where he spent much of the rest of his life. The "Hot Coffee mod" is a player-made software patch for "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas" that unlocked a previously hidden sexual scene in the game. This mod was created by Patrick Wildenborg, a modder from the Netherlands, and was released in mid-June 2005. The name "Hot Coffee" refers to the way the game alludes to the unseen sexual content, which became a significant controversy. Following the mod's release, the game faced scrutiny, leading to the Office of Film and Literature Classification in Australia revoking its original rating of MA15+, which prohibited its sale in that region. In response to the backlash, Rockstar North released an official "Cold Coffee" patch in August 2005 for the PC version, and subsequently re-released "San Andreas" with the "Hot Coffee" scenes removed, restoring its "M" rating (as referenced in the provided documents).

The maximum data rate for the 802.11a standard is 54 Mbit/s (which yields realistic net achievable throughput in the mid-20 Mbit/s) (IEEE 802.11; ratified in 1999).

range communications. The peak transmission rate of 802.11ay is 20 Gbit/s. The main extensions include: channel bonding (2, 3 and 4), MIMO and higher modulation schemes. Across all variations of 802.11, maximum achievable throughputs are given either based on measurements under ideal conditions or in the layer-2 data rates. However, this does not apply to typical deployments in which data is being transferred between two endpoints, of which at least one is typically connected to a wired infrastructure and the other endpoint is connected to an infrastructure via a wireless link. This means that, typically, data frames pass an 802.11

ratified in 1999. The 802.11a standard uses the same core protocol as the original standard, operates in 5 GHz band, and uses a 52-subcarrier orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) with a maximum raw data rate of 54 Mbit/s, which yields realistic net achievable throughput in the mid-20 Mbit/s. The data rate is reduced to 48, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9 then 6 Mbit/s if required. 802.11a originally had 12/13 non-overlapping channels, 12 that can be used indoor and 4/5 of the 12 that can be used in outdoor point to point configurations. Recently many countries of the world are allowing operation

interference, but locally there may be fewer signals to interfere with, resulting in less interference and better throughput. The 802.11b standard has a maximum raw data rate of 11 Mbit/s, and uses the same media access method defined in the original standard. 802.11b products appeared on the market in early 2000, since 802.11b is a direct extension of the modulation technique defined in the original standard. The dramatic increase in throughput of 802.11b (compared to the original standard) along with simultaneous substantial price reductions led to the rapid acceptance of 802.11b as the definitive wireless LAN technology. The state located in the center of India is Madhya Pradesh. It is part of the region referred to as Central India, which also includes Chhattisgarh (Central India is a loosely defined region of India consisting of the states of Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh).

Telangana Telangana () is a state in the south of India. It is situated on the centre-south stretch of the Indian peninsula on the high Deccan Plateau. It is the twelfth largest state and the twelfth-most populated state in India with a geographical area of and 35,193,978 residents as per 2011 census. On 2 June 2014, the area was separated from the northwestern part of Andhra Pradesh as the newly formed 29th state with Hyderabad as its historic permanent capital. Odisha Odisha (, ; , ) (formerly known as Orissa) is one of the 29 states of India. Located in eastern India, it is surrounded by the states of West Bengal to the north-east, Jharkhand to the north, Chhattisgarh to the west and north-west, and Andhra Pradesh to the south. Odisha has of coastline along the Bay of Bengal on its east, from Balasore to Ganjam. It is the 9th largest state by area, and the 11th largest by population. Central India Central India is a loosely defined region of India consisting of the states of Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh. Indore, the commercial capital of Madhya Pradesh is the largest city in the region. Other major cities include Bhopal and Raipur. The states share many linguistic and cultural characteristics with the Northern Region including the predominance of Hindi. The states of Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh have been grouped along with the states of Uttar Pradesh and Uttarakhand as the Northern Zonal Council for cooperation. The last name "Wallace" is of Scottish origin, derived from the Anglo-Norman French term "waleis," which itself comes from a cognate of the Old English word "wylisc," meaning "foreigner" or "Welshman" (Wallace (surname)). The surname may have originally referred to someone from the former Kingdom of Strathclyde, who spoke Cumbric, a language closely related to Welsh, or possibly to an incomer from Wales or the Welsh Marches (Wallace (surname)). The Kingdom of Strathclyde was part of the Hen Ogledd, where the inhabitants spoke a Brythonic language distinct from Scottish Gaelic and the English derived from Lothian (Wallace (surname)).

In Norway, new citizens make a "Pledge of Commitment," which includes a pledge of loyalty to Norway and support for democracy and human rights, without a mandatory oath requirement (as referenced: "Som norsk statsborger lover jeg troskap til mitt land Norge og det norske samfunnet, og jeg støtter demokratiet og menneskerettighetene og vil respektere landets lover" and "As a citizen of Norway I pledge loyalty to my country Norway and the Norwegian society, and I support democracy and human rights and will respect the laws of the country").

In Canada, new citizens must take the Oath of Citizenship, which is a legally binding commitment to obey the laws and customs of Canada and recognize the authority of the monarch (as referenced: "The Oath of Citizenship is today a legally binding oral and written contract intended to ensure that new Canadian citizens promise to obey the laws and customs of their new country..."). The English version of the oath is: "I swear (or affirm) that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Canada, Her Heirs and Successors, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Canada and fulfil my Oath of citizenship."

Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 was a scheduled flight operating on the route from Addis Ababa to Nairobi, with additional stops planned in Brazzaville, Lagos, and Abidjan. On November 23, 1996, the Boeing 767-200ER aircraft was hijacked by three Ethiopian nationals who were seeking asylum in Australia. The situation escalated, leading to the aircraft crash-landing in the Indian Ocean near Grande Comore due to fuel exhaustion. Tragically, 125 of the 175 passengers and crew on board, including the three hijackers, lost their lives in this incident. This event is noted as the only (partially) successful ditching of a wide-body airliner in history, and the crash was captured on video (Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961).

The plane crash-landed in the Indian Ocean near Grande Comore, Comoros Islands, due to fuel exhaustion; 125 of the 175 passengers and crew on board, including the three hijackers, died. Edmund Barton became the newly Federated Australian nation's first Prime Minister at a grand ceremony in Centennial Park, Sydney, on 1 January 1901. He and his cabinet were sworn in by Australia's first Governor-General, Lord Hopetoun before an estimated crowd of 250,000 people. Hopetoun had first offered the position to the Premier of New South Wales Sir William Lyne (an opponent of Federation), but the other members of Cabinet and the general population saw Barton as the logical choice. Howard was sworn in as the new Prime Minister of Australia on 11 March 1996, along with the First Howard Ministry. This was the first federal election that future Prime Minister Tony Abbott contested as a member of parliament, having entered parliament at the 1994 Warringah by-election. Future opposition leader Brendan Nelson entered parliament at this election. John Howard, who had previously led the Liberal Party from 1985 to 1989, had returned to the leadership in January 1995 following a disastrous 8 months under the leadership of Alexander Downer. of a national constitution, and was one of the lead campaigners for federation in the subsequent referendums. In late 1900, despite the initial "Hopetoun Blunder", Barton was commissioned to form a caretaker government as Australia's first prime minister. His term began on 1 January 1901, the date on which federation occurred. At the first federal elections in March 1901, Barton and the Protectionists won the most seats, but were well short of a majority. The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) was founded in Dhaka on 8 December 1985 (South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation).

South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation
The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) is the regional intergovernmental organization and geopolitical union of nations in South Asia. Its member states include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, the Maldives, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. SAARC comprises 3% of the world's area, 21% of the world's population and 3.8% (US$2.9 trillion) of the global economy, as of 2015. SAARC was founded in Dhaka on 8 December 1985. Its secretariat is based in Kathmandu, Nepal. The organization promotes development of economic and regional integration. It launched the South Asian Free Trade Area in

2006. SAARC maintains permanent diplomatic relations at the United Nations as an observer and has developed links with multilateral entities, including the European Union. <hr color="blue"> The idea of co-operation in South Asia was discussed in at least three conferences: the Asian Relations Conference held in New Delhi on April 1947; the Baguio Conference in the Philippines on May 1950; and the Colombo Powers Conference held in Sri Lanka in April 1954. In the ending years of the 1970s, the seven inner South Asian nations that included Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka agreed upon the creation

the formal inauguration of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) at a summit gathering of South Asian leaders in Dhaka in December 1985. The power to make decisions in courts of law is primarily held by judicial officers, which include judges and magistrates. These individuals are responsible for facilitating, arbitrating, presiding over, and making decisions regarding the application of the law (Judicial officer). They exercise judicial discretion, which allows them to make legal decisions within a range of possible outcomes, reflecting their independence and the doctrine of separation of powers (Judicial discretion). However, this discretion is bounded by legislation, binding precedent, and constitutional constraints to ensure that the rule of law is upheld (Judicial discretion).

In specific jurisdictions, such as Sri Lanka, judicial officers include District judges and Magistrates, who are appointed by the Judicial Service Commission (Judicial officer). In Kuwait, judicial officers possess various powers, including hearing writ petitions, appeals, and reviewing their own judgments, as well as trying certain cases as specified by law (Judicial officer). Additionally, the Supreme Court in various countries, such as Nepal, serves as the guardian of the Constitution and holds significant judicial powers, including rule-making and administrative oversight of lower courts (Judicial officer).

Judicial discretion Judicial discretion is the power of the judiciary to make some legal decisions according to their discretion. Under the doctrine of the separation of powers, the ability of judges to exercise discretion is an aspect of judicial independence. Where appropriate, judicial discretion allows a judge to decide a legal case or matter within a range of possible decisions. However, where the exercise of discretion goes beyond constraints set down by legislation, by binding precedent, or by a constitution, the court may be abusing its discretion and undermining the rule of law. In that case, the decision of the

Judicial officer A Judicial officer is a person with the responsibilities and powers to facilitate, arbitrate, preside over, and make decisions and directions in regard to the application of the law. Judicial officers are typically categorized as judges, magistrates, puisne judicial officers such as justices of the peace or officers of courts of limited jurisdiction; and notaries public and commissioners of oaths. The powers of judicial officers vary and are usually limited to a certain jurisdiction. In Sri Lanka, Judicial officers refer to District judges and Magistrates. They are appointed by the Judicial Service Commission. In Kuwait, Judicial Officers are

of hearing the writ petitions, the power of hearing appeal, the power of reviewing its own judgments, the power to revise the judgments delivered by the Court of Appeal and the power to try certain cases (as specified by law). You are referring to the renowned Islamic scholar and mathematician, Omar Khayyam, who died in 1131 CE. He made significant contributions to mathematics, particularly in the field of algebra and geometry. Khayyam is well-known for his work on the classification and solution of cubic equations, as well as for his contributions to the development of the Persian calendar. His poetic works, particularly the "Rubaiyat," also reflect his philosophical insights and understanding of the human condition.

During the period in which he lived, Islamic mathematics was at its peak, with scholars building upon the foundations laid by earlier mathematicians such as al-Khwarizmi and al-Kindi. The advancements made during this time were instrumental in the evolution of mathematics as a discipline, influencing both the Islamic world and later European mathematics (By the second half of the ninth century, Islamic mathematicians were already making contributions to the most sophisticated parts of Greek geometry. Islamic mathematics reached its apogee in the Eastern part of the Islamic world between the tenth and twelfth centuries.). 

Khayyam's legacy continues to be celebrated today, not only for his mathematical prowess but also for his literary contributions, which have transcended cultural and temporal boundaries.

By the second half of the ninth century, Islamic mathematicians were already making contributions to the most sophisticated parts of Greek geometry. Islamic mathematics reached its apogee in the Eastern part of the Islamic world between the tenth and twelfth centuries. Most mathematical works were written in Arabic, others in Persian. al-Khwarizmi (8th–9th centuries), considered the greatest mathematician of Islamic civilization, was instrumental in the adoption of the Indian numbering system. He developed algebra, which also had Indian antecedents, introduced methods of simplifying equations, and used Euclidean geometry in his proofs. The colors of the Netherlands flag are red, white, and blue, arranged in a horizontal tricolor pattern (Flag of the Netherlands).

Flag of the Netherlands The flag of the Netherlands () is a horizontal tricolor of red, white, and blue. The tricolor flag is almost identical to that of Luxembourg, except that it is shorter and its red and blue stripes are a darker shade. It originates as a variant of the older orange-white-blue "Prinsenvlag" ("Prince's Flag"), introduced in the 17th century as the "Statenvlag" ("States Flag"), the naval flag of the States-General of the Dutch Republic. Its official status as the national flag of the Kingdom of the Netherlands was formalized in 1937. The national flag of the Netherlands is

Statenvlag The Statenvlag ("States Flag") is the name of the flag of the States-General of the Dutch Republic, the red-white-blue tricolour flag replacing the older orange-white-blue Prince's Flag in the mid 17th century. The modern national flag of the Netherlands, officially introduced in 1937, is based on this historical flag. The origin of the red-white-blue tricolour is not entirely clear; some sources suggest that it developed merely as a variant of red-white-blue because the orange dye would tend to fade to red over time. However, there have also been suggestions to the effect that the red-white-blue flag might predate the

the red-white-blue "States Flag". According to de Waard (1900), the Dutch navy between 1588 and 1630 always displayed the Prince's Flag, and after 1663 always the States Flag, but both flag variants were in use during the period of 1630–1662. It appears that prior to 1664, the red-white-blue tricolor was commonly known as the "Flag of Holland" ("Hollandsche Vlag"). In 1664, the States of Zeeland complained about this, and a resolution of the States-General introduced the name "States Flag" ("Statenvlag"). In the 1930s, the supporters of the NSB chose the orange-white-blue and the Prince's Flag as their symbol. Queen Wilhelmina

The Lord's Prayer is found in two places in the New Testament: the longer version is located in the Gospel of Matthew (Matthew 6:9-13), and the shorter version can be found in the Gospel of Luke (Luke 11:2-4) (Lord's Prayer).

Lord's Prayer The Lord's Prayer (also called the Our Father or Pater Noster) is a venerated Christian prayer which, according to the New Testament, Jesus taught as the way to pray: Two versions of this prayer are recorded in the gospels: a longer form within the Sermon on the Mount in the Gospel of Matthew, and a shorter form in the Gospel of Luke when "one of his disciples said to him, 'Lord, teach us to pray, as John taught his disciples.'" Lutheran theologian Harold Buls suggested that both were original, the Matthaen version spoken by Jesus early in his

Prayer in the New Testament Prayer in the New Testament is presented as a positive command (; ). The People of God are challenged to include Christian prayer in their everyday life, even in the busy struggles of marriage () as it brings people closer to God. Jesus encouraged his disciples to pray in secret in their private rooms, using the Lord's Prayer, as a humble response to the prayer of the Pharisees, whose practices in prayer were regarded as impious by the New Testament writers (). Throughout the New Testament, prayer is shown to be God's appointed method by

The first centuries of Christianity witnessed an intense growth in religious literature and these often included prayers. The Ten Commandments are found in the Bible in two primary locations:

1. **Exodus 20:1-17** - This passage contains the initial presentation of the Ten Commandments, where God delivers them to Moses on Mount Sinai.
2. **Deuteronomy 5:4-21** - This passage provides a restatement of the Ten Commandments, as Moses recounts them to the Israelites before they enter the Promised Land.

These texts serve as the foundational ethical guidelines in both Judaism and Christianity, emphasizing the importance of worship, moral conduct, and community relationships.

Ten Commandments The Ten Commandments (, "Aseret ha'Dibrot"), also known as the Decalogue, are a set of biblical principles relating to ethics and worship, which play a fundamental role in Judaism and Christianity. The commandments include instructions to worship only God, to honour one's parents, and to keep the sabbath, as well as prohibitions against idolatry, blasphemy, murder, adultery, theft, dishonesty, and coveting. Different religious groups follow different traditions for interpreting and numbering them. The Ten Commandments appear twice in the Hebrew Bible, in the books of Exodus and Deuteronomy. The Ten Commandments are recognized as a moral foundation by Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. They first appear in the Book of Exodus, according to which Moses, acting under the orders of God, freed the Israelites from physical slavery in Egypt. According to Church teaching, God offered a covenant—which included the Ten Commandments—to also free them from the "spiritual slavery" of sin. Ten Commandments in Catholic theology The Ten Commandments are a series of religious and moral imperatives that are recognized as a moral foundation in several of the Abrahamic religions, including Catholicism. As described in the Old Testament books Exodus and Deuteronomy, the Commandments form part of a covenant offered by God to the Israelites to free them from the spiritual slavery of sin. According to the "Catechism of the Catholic Church"—the official exposition of the Catholic Church's Christian beliefs—the Commandments are considered essential for spiritual good health and growth, and serve as the basis for Catholic social teaching. After the Allies successfully expelled the Axis powers from North Africa in May 1943, they shifted their focus to the next phase of the war in Europe. The Allies launched a series of operations aimed at invading Italy, which was seen as a crucial step in weakening Axis control in Southern Europe. 

The first major operation following the North African Campaign was the invasion of Sicily, known as Operation Husky, which began on July 9, 1943. This operation aimed to secure the island and use it as a base for further operations into mainland Italy. Following the successful capture of Sicily, the Allies continued their campaign by landing on the Italian mainland at Salerno on September 9, 1943, and later capturing key cities such as Naples and Rome.

This progression from North Africa to Italy was part of the broader strategy to open up a new front against the Axis powers and to divert German resources from the Eastern Front, ultimately leading to the liberation of Europe.

Additionally, in medieval etymology, it was sometimes mistakenly thought to derive from the Latin "vera" (true) and Greek "eikon" (image) (Veronica (name)). "Veronica" is a popular name in many countries in the Mediterranean, Eastern Europe, and Latin America, as well as southern Ireland, France, and French-speaking Canada. Artery An artery (plural arteries) () is a blood vessel that takes blood away from the heart to all parts of the body (tissues, lungs, etc). Most arteries carry oxygenated blood; the two exceptions are the pulmonary and the umbilical arteries, which carry deoxygenated blood to the organs that oxygenate it. The effective arterial blood volume is that extracellular fluid which fills the arterial system. An object that moves around an external axis is said to undergo a revolution or orbital revolution, particularly when this movement is influenced by gravity (e.g., the Earth around the Sun) (Rotation).

Rotation A rotation is a circular movement of an object around a center (or point) of rotation. A three-dimensional object can always be rotated around an infinite number of imaginary lines called "rotation axes" ( ). If the axis passes through the body's center of mass, the body is said to rotate upon itself, or spin. A rotation about an external point, e.g. the Earth about the Sun, is called a revolution or orbital revolution, typically when it is produced by gravity. The axis is called a pole. Mathematically, a rotation is a rigid body movement which, unlike a translation,

Wells Cathedral, constructed beginning in 1175, is notable for its innovative architectural elements, particularly its rib vaults. The vaults, designed by William Joy in the 14th century, feature a complex network of ribs that create a net-like appearance, distinguishing them from the simpler vaults of the nave. This design may reflect a local tradition of compartmented wooden roofs, as seen in examples from the 15th century at St Cuthbert's Church, Wells (origin text). 

The cathedral is recognized as the first Gothic cathedral in England, with its architects moving away from the Romanesque features that characterized earlier structures, such as the east end of Canterbury Cathedral and the Abbey of Saint Denis (origin text). Instead of traditional columns, Wells employs clustered piers, enhancing the verticality and lightness typical of Gothic architecture. The vaults also incorporate lierne ribs that form octagons at the center of each compartment, with decorative bosses at the joints of the ribs, adding to the visual complexity of the interior (origin text).

Additionally, the design of the eastern range of the cathedral includes a two-storey structure, with the upper level serving as a library built in the 15th century. Unlike many monastic cathedrals, Wells Cathedral was secular, which influenced the decision to include cloisters, a feature that was omitted in several other secular cathedrals (origin text). The presence of cloisters at Wells and Chichester may have served both processional and aesthetic purposes, contributing to the overall grandeur of the cathedral's design (origin text).

of the 14th century by William Joy. The vault has a multiplicity of ribs in a net-like form, which is very different from that of the nave, and is perhaps a recreation in stone of a local type of compartmented wooden roof of which examples remain from the 15th century, including those at St Cuthbert's Church, Wells. The vaults of the aisles of the choir also have a unique pattern. Until the early 14th century, the interior of the cathedral was in a unified style, but it was to undergo two significant changes, to the tower and to the eastern

the cathedral began in about 1175, to the design of an unknown architect. Wells is the first cathedral in England to be, from its foundation, built in the Gothic style. According to art historian John Harvey, it is the first truly Gothic cathedral in the world, its architects having entirely dispensed with all the features that bound the contemporary east end of Canterbury Cathedral and the earlier buildings of France, such as the east end of the Abbey of Saint Denis, to the Romanesque. Unlike these churches, Wells has clustered piers rather than columns and has a gallery of identical

mullions and transoms, and tracery in the Perpendicular Gothic style. The vault has lierne ribs that form octagons at the centre of each compartment, the joints of each rib having decorative bosses. The eastern range is of two storeys, of which the upper is the library built in the 15th century. Because Wells Cathedral was secular rather than monastic, cloisters were not a practical necessity. They were omitted from several other secular cathedrals but were built here and at Chichester. They prefer arid lowland or mountainous shrubland and are widely dispersed in dry open country with scattered brush. They are non-migratory, staying in their breeding area year-round (Roadrunner; "Roadrunners inhabit the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central America. and generally prefer sprinting to flying, though it will fly to escape predators. During flight, the short, rounded wings reveal a white crescent in the primary feathers. The roadrunner has a slow and descending dove-like "coo". It also makes a rapid, vocalized clattering sound with its beak. Roadrunners inhabit the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central America. They live in arid lowland or mountainous shrubland, widely dispersed in dry open country with scattered brush. They are non-migratory, staying in their breeding area year-round. The greater roadrunner is not currently considered threatened in the US, but is habitat-limited.

The roadrunner is an opportunistic omnivore. Its diet normally consists of insects (such as grasshoppers, crickets, caterpillars, and beetles), small reptiles (such as lizards, collared lizards, and snakes, including rattlesnakes), rodents and other small mammals, spiders (including tarantulas), scorpions, centipedes, snails, small birds (and nestlings), eggs, and fruits and seeds like those from prickly pear cactuses and sumacs. The lesser roadrunner eats mainly insects. The roadrunner forages on the ground and, when hunting, usually runs after prey from under cover. It may leap to catch insects, and commonly batters certain prey against the ground. Because of its quickness, the roadrunner

is one of the few animals that preys upon rattlesnakes; it is also the only real predator of tarantula hawk wasps. The roadrunner usually lives alone or in pairs. Breeding pairs are monogamous and mate for life, and pairs may hold a territory all year. During the courtship display, the male bows, alternately lifting and dropping his wings and spreading his tail. He parades in front of the female with his head high and his tail and wings drooped, and may bring an offering of food. Ram Nath Kovind ultimately won the election and became the 14th President of India (2017 Indian presidential election).

2017 Indian presidential election A presidential election was held in India on 17 July 2017 with the votes counted and the results announced on 20 July 2017. Ram Nath Kovind became 14th President of India. President Pranab Mukherjee, whose term of office was due to expire on 24 July 2017, declined to seek re-election due to health concerns. Governor of Bihar Ram Nath Kovind of the Bharatiya Janata Party had the backing of the governing National Democratic Alliance coalition, and went up against opposition candidate Meira Kumar of the Indian National Congress in the vote. Cigarette advertising on television was banned starting on January 2, 1971, following the passage of the Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act in 1970 (anti-smoking advertisements at no cost to the organizations providing such advertisements). The last commercial aired just before the ban, with the Virginia Slims brand's advertisement shown at 11:59 p.m. on January 1, 1971 (In April 1970, President Nixon signed it into law).

anti-smoking advertisements at no cost to the organizations providing such advertisements. In 1970, Congress took their anti-smoking initiative one step further and passed the Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act, banning the advertising of cigarettes on television and radio starting on January 2, 1971. In April 1970, President Nixon signed it into law. The Virginia Slims brand was the last commercial shown, with "a 60-second revue from flapper to Female Lib", shown at 11:59 p.m. on 1 January during a break on "The Tonight Show". After the television ban, most cigarette advertising took place in magazines, newspapers, and on billboards. Smokeless

advertising on newspapers and magazines was strictly prohibited, under the Prohibition of Advertisements relating to Smoking Act, 1970. Tobacco advertisements on radio, television and on neon signs ceased on 31 December 1970, after which only anti-smoking slogans were permitted to be broadcast on television and radio. With the ban on tobacco advertisements for the purpose of anti-smoking, the Ministry of Culture had appealed to coffee shops, hotels, restaurants, canteens, snack bars and bars to co-operate with the government to remove all posters, signs and other forms of advertisements relating to smoking. A Smoking Advertisement Unit was set up by the

College of Physicians, who highlighted the health problems and recommended stricter laws on the sale and advertising of tobacco products. In 1971, an agreement between the government and the tobacco industry saw the inclusion of health warnings on all cigarette packets. All television commercials for cigarettes were banned on 1 August 1965, although commercials for loose tobacco and cigars continued until 1991. Non-television advertising campaigns were still allowed in the UK but came under stricter guidelines in 1986, which in particular, prevented adverts from actually showing a person smoking. Points on a sphere or angles in a circle are measured in units called **radians** and **degrees**. The angle subtended at the center of a circle, measured in radians, is equal to the ratio of the length of the enclosed arc to the length of the circle's radius. Since the units of measurement cancel, this ratio is dimensionless (the angle measure is still dimensionless). The radian is widely used in physics when angular measurements are required, such as in angular velocity, which is typically measured in radians per second (rad/s) (from the definition given earlier).

In terms of angular measurement, the measure of the angle "AOC" is the sum of the measures of angles AOB and BOC. It does not matter in which unit the angle is measured as long as each angle is measured in the same unit. A full circle, measured in right-ascension units, contains 24 hours (of rotation of the Earth), which can be used to time the positions (of celestial objects) (of a circle is measured as 1 of right ascension, or 15°).

The oligodynamic effect is a phenomenon that describes the antimicrobial properties of certain metals, particularly in relation to their ability to inhibit the growth of bacteria and other microorganisms. This effect is significant in various applications, including medical devices and water purification systems.

In discussing the broader implications of causality and interconnected events, the concept of the domino effect is relevant. A domino effect or chain reaction refers to the cumulative impact produced when one event triggers a series of similar events, akin to a falling row of dominoes (Domino effect; theory). This analogy highlights how interconnected systems can lead to significant outcomes from seemingly minor initial events.

Additionally, the butterfly effect theory suggests that small variations in the initial conditions of a nonlinear dynamical system can lead to substantial changes in the system's long-term behavior (butterfly effect theory). This concept further emphasizes the complexity of causality and the potential for distributed causality in various systems, including those influenced by the oligodynamic effect.

The at sign, represented by the symbol "@", is commonly referred to as the "at symbol" or "commercial at." It is primarily used in email addresses and social media handles, but it also has historical uses in accounting and invoices to mean "at a rate of" (e.g., 7 widgets @ £2 = £14) (At sign). Additionally, in East Asia, it is sometimes called "alphasand" (At sign). Other terms that have been coined for the symbol include "ampersat," "asperand," and "strudel," though none of these have gained widespread acceptance (At sign).

At sign The at sign", @, is normally read aloud as "at"; it is also commonly called the at symbol or commercial at"'. It is used as an accounting and invoice abbreviation meaning "at a rate of" (e.g. 7 widgets @ £2 = £14), but it is now most commonly used in email addresses and social media platform "handles". The term "alphasand" is sometimes used to refer to "@", especially in East Asia. Although not included on the keyboard of the earliest commercially successful typewriters, it was on at least one 1889 model and the very successful Underwood models from

the "Underwood No. 5" in 1900 onward. It started to be used in email addresses in the 1970s, and is now universally included on computer keyboards. The fact that there is no single word in English for the symbol has prompted some writers to use the French arobase or Spanish and Portuguese arroba, or to coin new words such as the "highly logical" ampersat, asperand, and the strudel, but none of these has achieved wide use. In unicode, the at sign is encoded as , or codice_1 in HTML5. The earliest yet discovered reference to the @ symbol is a

religious one; it features in a Bulgarian translation of a Greek chronicle written by Constantinos Manasses in 1345. Held today in the Vatican Apostolic Library, it features the @ symbol in place of the capital letter alpha "A" in the word Amen. Why it was used in this context is still a mystery. In terms of the commercial character of the "at" sign, there are several theories pending verification. Whatever the origin of the @ symbol, the history of its usage is more well-known: it has long been used in Spanish and Portuguese as an abbreviation of "arroba", a unit

The Forbidden City was ordered to be built by the Yongle Emperor, who was the third emperor of the Ming dynasty. Construction began in 1406 and lasted for 14 years, involving a massive workforce of skilled artisans and laborers. The design and planning of the Forbidden City were overseen by various architects and the Emperor's Ministry of Work, with notable contributions from chief architects such as Cai Xin and Kuai Xiang. The construction was a monumental effort that utilized precious materials and extensive labor to create what would become the imperial palace of China.

Construction lasted 14 years and employed the work of 100,000 skilled artisans and up to a million labourers. In the U.S. Constitution, the power to approve or veto legislation is primarily held by the President of the United States. According to the Constitution, the President may sign a bill into law or veto it, returning it to Congress with objections (U.S. Constitution, Article I, Section 7). If the President vetoes a bill, Congress can override the veto with a two-thirds majority vote in both the House of Representatives and the Senate (U.S. Constitution, Article I, Section 7). Additionally, if the President takes no action on a bill for ten days while Congress is in session, the bill automatically becomes law (U.S. Constitution, Article I, Section 7). 

This system exemplifies the principle of "checks and balances," where the legislative branch (Congress) creates laws, while the executive branch (the President) has the authority to approve or reject them, ensuring that no single branch holds too much power.

the U.S. Constitution is the idea of "checks and balances" among the powers and responsibilities of the three branches of American government: the executive, the legislative, and the judiciary. For example, while the legislative branch (Congress) has the power to create law, the executive branch under the president can veto any legislation—an act which, in turn, can be overridden by Congress. The president nominates judges to the nation's highest judiciary authority, the Supreme Court, but those nominees must be approved by Congress. The Supreme Court, in turn, can invalidate unconstitutional laws passed by the Congress. These and other examples are

Finally, the president may choose to take no action, neither signing nor vetoing the bill. The transition from command to market economies in Eastern Europe had significant initial effects, characterized by economic turmoil and varying reform strategies across different countries. One of the most notable outcomes was a temporary decline in official economic output, coupled with a rise in black market activities, as the region grappled with the shift from socialism to capitalism. Many citizens had little to no experience with market economies, leading to a widespread belief that these countries would remain impoverished for decades (view was that there was no precedent for moving from socialism to capitalism).

Countries adopted diverse reform programs in response to the economic crisis. For instance, Poland's "shock therapy," known as the Balcerowicz Plan, is often cited as a successful example of rapid economic reform. This approach aimed to stabilize the economy quickly, and although it initially led to hardship, it eventually set the stage for economic growth (One example, generally regarded as successful was the "shock therapy" Balcerowicz Plan in Poland. Eventually the official economy began to grow).

The transition was complicated by the historical context of each country, including their levels of development, trade isolation, and the distortions inherent in their socialist planned economies. The overarching goal of these reforms was to transform these economies into capitalist market systems, often at the expense of immediate economic growth and welfare (the overriding objective was the transformation to capitalist market economies rather than the fostering of economic growth and welfare). By the year 2000, reports indicated that the initial conditions of each country had less impact on the reform processes, suggesting that the foundations for functioning market economies were being established (the effects of the initial starting point in each transition economy on the reform process had faded).

Overall, while the transition was fraught with challenges, it laid the groundwork for future economic development in the region, albeit with varying degrees of success and different trajectories among the countries involved.

Thus, while the Proclamation itself was issued on October 7, 1763, its practical governance ended with the enactment of the Quebec Act in 1774.

The Royal Proclamation of 1763 had been issued in October, by King George III following Great Britain's acquisition of French territory. "One Piece at a Time" is a country novelty song written by Wayne Kemp and recorded by Johnny Cash and the Tennessee Three in 1976. The song tells the story of a man who works at General Motors in Detroit, Michigan, and over the years, he builds a car by taking parts from various Cadillacs as they roll by on the assembly line. This unique approach allows him to create a vehicle that is a compilation of different models and years, reflecting his resourcefulness and creativity. The song features a moderate tempo in the key of F major and employs a talking blues style, similar to Cash's earlier hit "A Boy Named Sue" (One Piece at a Time). 

The song became notable for being the last one performed by Cash to reach number one on the Billboard Hot Country Singles chart and also marked the end of his songs reaching the Billboard Hot 100, where it peaked at number 29 (One Piece at a Time).

The normal blood clotting process, or hemostasis, occurs in three distinct phases:

1. **Vascular Spasm**: This is the initial response to blood vessel injury. The blood vessels constrict to reduce blood flow and minimize blood loss. This immediate reaction helps to limit the amount of blood that escapes from the damaged area (as referenced in "During hemostasis three steps occur in a rapid sequence. Vascular spasm is the first response as the blood vessels constrict to allow less blood to be lost.").

2. **Platelet Plug Formation**: Following the vascular spasm, platelets adhere to the site of injury and to each other, forming a temporary seal known as a platelet plug. This step is crucial for providing an initial barrier against further bleeding (as noted in "In the second step, platelet plug formation, platelets stick together to form a temporary seal to cover the break in the vessel wall.").

3. **Coagulation**: The final phase involves the transformation of liquid blood into a gel-like substance, reinforcing the platelet plug with fibrin threads. This process, known as coagulation or blood clotting, effectively stabilizes the platelet plug and forms a more durable clot that will remain until the tissue is repaired (as indicated in "The third and last step is called coagulation or blood clotting. Coagulation reinforces the platelet plug with fibrin threads that act as a 'molecular glue'.").

Together, these three phases work in concert to prevent excessive blood loss and facilitate healing after vascular injury.

The oldest street in the Philippines is Colon Street, located in downtown Cebu City. It is often referred to as the oldest and shortest national road in the country. The street is named after Cristóbal Colón (Christopher Columbus) and traces its origins to the town plan established by Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, the Spanish conquistador who arrived in the Philippines in 1565. Historically, Colon Street was once a bustling area filled with fashionable shops, offices, and movie houses, serving as the heart of Cebu City's shopping district (Colon Street).

The Great Wall of China was primarily built to defend against incursions by nomadic groups from Inner Asia, particularly the Huns during the Qin Dynasty, the Turks during the Tang Dynasty, and later the Mongolians and Central Asians (History of the Great Wall of China; built and guarded the Great Wall). The construction of the wall was a response to the threats posed by these nomadic tribes, especially during periods of significant conflict, such as the establishment of the Yuan Dynasty by the Mongols under Kublai Khan (History of the Great Wall of China).

History of the Great Wall of China The history of the Great Wall of China began when fortifications built by various states during the Spring and Autumn (771–476) and Warring States periods (475–221) were connected by the first emperor of China, Qin Shi Huang, to protect his newly founded Qin dynasty (221–206) against incursions by nomads from Inner Asia. The walls were built of rammed earth, constructed using forced labour, and by 212 ran from Gansu to the coast of southern Manchuria. Later dynasties adopted different policies towards northern frontier defense. The Han (202 – 220), the Northern Qi (550–574),

In the context of email communication, "CC" stands for "Carbon Copy," and "BCC" stands for "Blind Carbon Copy." 

- **CC (Carbon Copy)**: This feature allows the sender to send a copy of the email to additional recipients. All recipients can see who else received the email, as the addresses of those in the CC field are visible to everyone.

- **BCC (Blind Carbon Copy)**: This feature also allows the sender to send a copy of the email to additional recipients, but the key difference is that recipients in the BCC field are hidden from all other recipients. This means that those in the "To" and "CC" fields cannot see the email addresses of those in the BCC field.

These terms originated from the practice of using carbon paper to create copies of documents, which is reflected in their names.

If a person is born on February 29, they are often referred to as a "leapling" or "leap-year baby." In non-leap years, they typically celebrate their birthday on either February 28 or March 1, although some choose to only observe their birthday on the actual date of February 29 when it occurs (as noted in the text: "In non-leap years, some leaplings celebrate their birthday on either February 28 or March 1, while others only observe birthdays on the authentic intercalary date, February 29"). The legal recognition of their birthday in non-leap years can vary by jurisdiction, which may affect how they celebrate (as mentioned: "The effective legal date of a leapling's birthday in non-leap years varies between jurisdictions").

Birthday A birthday is the anniversary of the birth of a person, or figuratively of an institution. Birthdays of people are celebrated in numerous cultures, often with birthday gifts, birthday cards, a birthday party, or a rite of passage. Many religions celebrate the birth of their founders or religious figures with special holidays (e.g. Christmas, Mawlid, Buddha's Birthday, and Krishna Janmashtami). There is a distinction between birth"day" and birth"date": The former, other than February 29, occurs each year (e.g. January 15), while the latter is the exact date a person was born (e.g., January 15, 2001). New York City's drinking water primarily comes from the protected Catskill Mountains watershed, which features an undisturbed natural water filtration system. This allows the city to be one of only four major cities in the United States whose drinking water is pure enough not to require purification by water treatment plants. The city's municipal water system is the largest in the United States, delivering over one billion gallons of water per day to more than eight million residents, as well as one million additional users in surrounding upstate counties (document reference). 

The water supply is sourced from three separate sub-systems consisting of aqueducts and reservoirs, with the Croton Watershed also contributing to the supply. The latter two aqueducts provide 90% of the city's drinking water, and the watershed for these aqueducts covers a significant area, with two-fifths owned by government entities or private conservancies (document reference). 

To ensure water quality, New York City has established 965 sampling stations distributed based on various factors such as population density and water pressure zones. These stations are used by the New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to collect over 1,200 water samples monthly from numerous locations (document reference).

Plants capture approximately 3% to 6% of total solar radiation for photosynthesis. In terms of sunlight-to-biomass efficiency, most crop plants store about 0.25% to 0.5% of the sunlight in their products (corn kernels, potato starch, etc.) (origin text). Additionally, after accounting for various losses during the photosynthetic process, the overall efficiency can be as low as 5.4% when considering the energy collected as sugar after respiration losses (origin text).

In actuality, however, plants do not absorb all incoming sunlight (due to reflection, respiration requirements of photosynthesis and the need for optimal solar radiation levels) and do not convert all harvested energy into biomass, which results in an overall photosynthetic efficiency of 3 to 6% of total solar radiation. If photosynthesis is inefficient, excess light energy must be dissipated to avoid damaging the photosynthetic apparatus. The economic system utilized in the Soviet Union was characterized as a command economy, also known as an administered economy. This system was based on state ownership of the means of production, collective farming, and industrial manufacturing, with centralized administrative planning guiding economic activities. The economy featured state control of investment, public ownership of industrial assets, and macroeconomic stability, resulting in negligible unemployment and high job security. Beginning in 1928, the Soviet economy was directed by a series of five-year plans, which facilitated the rapid transformation from a primarily agrarian society to a major industrial power by the 1950s. Enterprises in the Soviet Union operated under a hierarchical structure, where directives were issued to lower-level organizations, indicating a lack of functional resource allocation through planning (Economy of the Soviet Union; Enterprises in the Soviet Union).

Economy of the Soviet Union The economy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics () was based on a system of state ownership of the means of production, collective farming, industrial manufacturing and centralized administrative planning. The economy was characterised by state control of investment, public ownership of industrial assets, macroeconomic stability, negligible unemployment and high job security. Beginning in 1928, the course of the Soviet Union's economy was guided by a series of five-year plans. By the 1950s, during the preceding few decades the Soviet Union had rapidly evolved from a mainly agrarian society into a major industrial power.

An enterprise was the general equivalent of "company", which was the legal entity prominent outside of the Eastern-bloc economies. World War II is widely regarded as having been initiated by Germany, specifically through its invasion of Poland on September 1, 1939. This act of aggression prompted Britain and France to declare war on Germany on September 3, 1939, marking the official start of the conflict. The roots of the war can be traced back to the aftermath of World War I, where the Treaty of Versailles placed the blame for the war and its damages squarely on Germany, leading to significant revanchism and dissatisfaction within the country (Events preceding World War II in Europe; Causes of World War II).

The rise of fascism in Italy and the militaristic expansion of Japan also contributed to the tensions leading up to the war. However, it was Adolf Hitler's aggressive foreign policy and the political takeover of Germany by the Nazi Party in 1933 that set the stage for the conflict. The perceived impotence of the League of Nations to curb these aggressive actions further exacerbated the situation, ultimately leading to the outbreak of World War II (Causes of World War II).

Events preceding World War II in Europe The events preceding World War II in Europe are closely tied to the rise of fascism, especially in Nazi Germany and communism, especially in the Soviet Union. World War II is generally viewed as having its roots in the aftermath of World War I. In that war, the German Empire under Kaiser Wilhelm II, with its allies, was defeated, chiefly by the United Kingdom, France, and the United States. The victors blamed Germany entirely for the war and all resulting damages; it was Germany that effectively started the war with an attack on

Causes of World War II Among the causes of World War II were Italian fascism in the 1920s, Japanese militarism and invasion of China in the 1930s, and especially the political takeover in 1933 of Germany by Adolf Hitler and his Nazi Party and its aggressive foreign policy. The immediate cause was Germany invading Poland on September 1, 1939, and Britain and France declaring war on Germany on September 3, 1939. Problems arose in Weimar Germany that experienced strong currents of revanchism after the Treaty of Versailles that concluded its defeat in World War I in 1918. Dissatisfactions of treaty

Italy and Germany also began engaging in militaristic campaigns designed to either enlarge their borders or to expand their sphere of military control, and the League was shown to be powerless to stop them. The perceived impotency of the League was a contributing factor which eventually led to the full outbreak of World War II in 1939. The start of World War II is generally dated from the event of Germany's invasion of Poland. It is noteworthy that Germany claimed at the time that its invasion of Poland was in fact a 'defensive war,' as it had allegedly been invaded

The commandment regarding taking the Lord's name in vain is found in Exodus 20:7, which states: "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain" (KJV). This commandment serves as a prohibition against blasphemy and the misuse of God's name, emphasizing the importance of honoring and respecting it. Variants of this commandment, such as "You shall not make wrongful use of the name of the Lord your God" (NRSV), highlight the seriousness of this directive.

Matthew Henry elaborated on this commandment by identifying five categories of actions that constitute taking God's name in vain: 1) hypocrisy—professing God's name without living according to His standards; 2) covenant breaking—failing to fulfill promises made to God; 3) rash swearing; 4) false swearing; and 5) using the name of the Lord inappropriately (KJV). This understanding underscores the significance of integrity and sincerity in one's relationship with God.

2016 UEFA Women's Champions League Final The 2016 UEFA Women's Champions League Final was the final match of the 2015–16 UEFA Women's Champions League, the 15th season of Europe's premier women's club football tournament organised by UEFA, and the seventh season since it was renamed from the UEFA Women's Cup to the UEFA Women's Champions League. It was played at the Mapei Stadium – Città del Tricolore stadium in Reggio Emilia, Italy, on 26 May 2016, between German team Wolfsburg and French team Lyon. The Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC), commonly known as the Dewey Decimal System, originated in the United States and was first published by Melvil Dewey in 1876. Initially presented in a four-page pamphlet, the system has since undergone significant expansion and revision, resulting in multiple volumes and 23 major editions, with the latest printed in 2011. The system is maintained by OCLC, a non-profit cooperative that serves libraries, which also provides online access to a continuously updated version known as WebDewey (Dewey Decimal Classification).

The DDC introduced the concepts of "relative location" and "relative way," allowing it to align with the physical arrangement of library shelves. This feature enables catalogers to use the classification as both an entry point and an index for navigating Dewey-classed libraries. The numbers generated by the Dewey Decimal Classification also served as the foundation for the Universal Decimal Classification (UDC), which incorporates Dewey numbers along with specific punctuation marks (Dewey Decimal Classification).

The system has been adapted for various regions outside the English-speaking world, leading to the creation of classifications such as the Korean Decimal Classification, the New Classification Scheme for Chinese Libraries, and the Nippon Decimal Classification in Japan. Despite its widespread adoption, the DDC faced competition from other classification systems, notably the French "Classification Decimal," which influenced its development (Dewey Decimal Classification). By 1927, a study indicated that the Dewey system was utilized by approximately 96% of public libraries and 89% of college libraries in the United States (Dewey Decimal Classification). After Melvil Dewey's death in 1931, the administration of the classification transitioned to the Decimal Classification Committee of the Lake Placid Club Education Foundation, with editorial oversight provided by the Decimal Classification Editorial Policy Committee (Dewey Decimal Classification).

The story of "The Jungle Book" has diverse origins and has been influenced by various cultural narratives. While Rudyard Kipling's version, published in 1894, is the most recognized, the themes and elements of the story can be traced back to multiple sources. For instance, variations of the tale exist in Nigeria, Thailand, and Tibet, suggesting that the story's roots may not be solely Greek as previously thought. The Thai account, which claims to derive from a Buddhist Jataka tale, lacks a specific source for comparison, indicating that the story has evolved across cultures (appearance of other tellings of the story, with local variations, from Nigeria, Thailand and Tibet, seems to call in question the purely Greek origin of the story). 

Additionally, the narrative has been adapted into various forms, including films and other media. The 1994 live-action adaptation by Disney, co-written and directed by Stephen Sommers, is one such example, showcasing the enduring appeal of Mowgli's adventures (The Jungle Book (1994 film) Rudyard Kipling's The Jungle Book is a 1994 live-action American adventure film co-written and directed by Stephen Sommers). The adaptations often introduce new characters and plot elements, reflecting the ongoing reinterpretation of Kipling's original work (abducted by a band of nameless and leaderless bandar-log monkeys, but the rest of the scene plays out very differently from Disney's version). 

Overall, "The Jungle Book" is a rich tapestry of storytelling that draws from various cultural influences and has been reshaped through numerous adaptations over time.

The Rational Dress Society was founded in 1881 in London (Rational Dress Society). Its purpose was to protest against fashion trends that deformed the figure, impeded movement, or harmed health, specifically opposing tightly-fitting corsets, high-heeled shoes, and heavily-weighted skirts (Rational Dress Society). The society emerged in response to the restrictive dress norms of the era, which had been a topic of discussion since the 1850s (Rational Dress Society).

Rational Dress Society The Rational Dress Society was an organisation founded in 1881 in London. It protests against the wearing of tightly-fitting corsets; of high-heeled shoes; of heavily-weighted skirts, as rendering healthy exercise almost impossible; and of all tie down cloaks or other garments impeding on the movements of the arms. Epidemiologists attempt to explain the link between health and various variables, focusing on discovering causal relationships rather than merely identifying correlations. A fundamental principle in epidemiology is that "correlation does not imply causation," emphasizing that while an association between two variables is necessary, it is not sufficient to conclude that one causes the other (epidemiology is sometimes viewed as a collection of statistical tools used to elucidate the associations of exposures to health outcomes). Epidemiologists gather data and utilize a range of biomedical and psychosocial theories to make inferences about these relationships (the key is in the term inference).

Moreover, the field of epidemiology intersects with social sciences, where health and disease are used to explain social phenomena, such as the emergence of lay health advocacy movements (intersecting social science fields often use health and disease in order to explain specifically social phenomenon). Social epidemiologists, in particular, focus on how social concepts can elucidate patterns of health within populations. Recently, there has been a shift towards identifying effective policies and interventions to address socioeconomic inequalities in health, which has led to discussions about the potential emergence of Political Epidemiology (the discipline is moving from identifying health inequalities along the social gradient to identifying the policies, programmes and interventions that effectively tackle the observed socioeconomic inequalities in health).

Epidemiological studies can be categorized into observational and experimental types. In observational studies, researchers observe natural occurrences without intervention, while in experimental studies, they control various factors to study their effects (in observational studies, nature is allowed to "take its course," as epidemiologists observe from the sidelines). The ultimate goal of these studies is to reveal unbiased relationships between exposures—such as alcohol, smoking, biological agents, stress, or chemicals—and health outcomes like mortality or morbidity (aimed, where possible, at revealing unbiased relationships between exposures such as alcohol or smoking, biological agents, stress, or chemicals to mortality or morbidity). Identifying causal relationships between these exposures and health outcomes is a critical focus of modern epidemiology (the identification of causal relationships between these exposures and outcomes is an important aspect of epidemiology).

"Swan Lake," "The Sleeping Beauty," and "The Nutcracker" are three famous ballets composed by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky. 

"Swan Lake," composed between 1875 and 1876, is based on an ancient German legend and tells the story of Odette, a princess cursed to become a swan by an evil sorcerer. Initially choreographed by Julius Reisinger, it premiered at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow. Despite its initial failure, it has become one of the most popular ballets worldwide (Swan Lake; Swan Lake (1895)).

"The Sleeping Beauty" is noted for its characterful musical invention, which is more striking than that found in "Swan Lake." The ballet features character pieces from fairy tales, such as "Puss in Boots" and "Little Red Riding Hood," showcasing Tchaikovsky's individualized musical creativity. This, combined with a well-structured plot and atmospheric feeling, makes "The Sleeping Beauty" arguably Tchaikovsky's most consistently successful ballet (The Sleeping Beauty).

"The Nutcracker," another of Tchaikovsky's best-known works, is celebrated for its enchanting music and festive themes, particularly popular during the holiday season. Each of these ballets showcases Tchaikovsky's unique ability to blend narrative and music, contributing to their enduring legacy in the world of dance.

Likewise, the musical ideas in these sections are more striking, pointed and precise. This characterful musical invention, combined with a structural fluency, a keen feeling for atmosphere and a well-structured plot, makes "The Sleeping Beauty" perhaps Tchaikovsky's most consistently successful ballet. The database related to library literature and information science can be classified primarily as a **bibliographic database** and a **full-text database**. Bibliographic databases contain metadata about various documents, such as books, articles, and other scholarly works, while full-text databases provide the complete text of these documents (e.g., books, dissertations, journals, magazines, newspapers) (origin text). 

Additionally, the evolution of library and information science has seen the integration of information retrieval techniques, particularly with the entry of information scientists into library schools in 1964, which emphasized competencies in handling subject databases (origin text). This reflects a broader trend in the field where databases are utilized not only for bibliographic purposes but also for managing and retrieving comprehensive textual information (origin text). 

In summary, the databases in library literature and information science can be categorized as both bibliographic and full-text databases, serving different but complementary roles in the management and dissemination of information.

the other hand has mostly concentrated on libraries and their internal processes and best practices. It is also relevant to consider that information science used to be done by scientists, while librarianship has been split between public libraries and scholarly research libraries. Library schools have mainly educated librarians for public libraries and not shown much interest in scientific communication and documentation. When information scientists from 1964 entered library schools, they brought with them competencies in relation to information retrieval in subject databases, including concepts such as recall and precision, boolean search techniques, query formulation and related issues. Subject bibliographic databases

Full-text database A full-text database or a complete-text database is a database that contains the complete text of books, dissertations, journals, magazines, newspapers or other kinds of textual documents. They differ from bibliographic databases (which contain only bibliographical metadata, including abstracts in some cases) and non-bibliographic databases (such as directories and numeric databases). One of the earliest systems was IBM STAIRS, introduced in 1973. Full-text databases became common about 1990 when computer storage technology made them economic and technologically possible. There are two main classes: an extension of the classical bibliographical databases into full-text databases (e.g. on hosts such as

software). Databases are used to hold administrative information and more specialized data, such as engineering data or economic models. Examples include computerized library systems, flight reservation systems, computerized parts inventory systems, and many content management systems that store websites as collections of webpages in a database. One way to classify databases involves the type of their contents, for example: bibliographic, document-text, statistical, or multimedia objects. The death penalty in the United States has its origins in the early colonial period, as it was implemented from the beginning of the American colonies. The first recorded executions occurred on January 5, 1849, when two Native Americans were hanged for murder (Capital punishment in the United States). The practice of capital punishment has evolved over time, with significant changes in its legal status, including its abolition in 1914 and subsequent reinstatement in 1919 (Capital punishment debate in the United States).

Capital punishment in the United States Capital punishment is a legal penalty in the United States, currently used by 30 states, the federal government, and the military. Its existence can be traced to the beginning of the American colonies. The United States is the only Western country currently applying the death penalty. It is one of 54 countries worldwide applying it, and was the first to develop lethal injection as a method of execution, which has since been adopted by five other countries. The Philippines has since abolished executions, and Guatemala has done so for civil offenses, leaving the USA

Capital punishment debate in the United States Capital punishment debate in the United States existed as early as the colonial period. As of 2017 it remains a legal penalty in 31 states, the federal government, and military criminal justice systems. Gallup, Inc. monitors support for the death penalty in the United States since 1937 by asking "Are you in favor of the death penalty for a person convicted of murder?" Coffee was first made into a drink in the early 15th century, specifically in the Sufi monasteries of Yemen. This is the earliest substantiated evidence of coffee drinking or knowledge of the coffee tree (History of coffee). The beverage was used by Sufis as an aid to concentration and as a form of spiritual intoxication during their practices (History of coffee).

History of coffee The history of coffee dates back to the 15th century, and possibly earlier with a number of reports and legends surrounding its first use. The native (undomesticated) origin of coffee is thought to have been Ethiopia, with several mythical accounts but no solid evidence. The earliest substantiated evidence of either coffee drinking or knowledge of the coffee tree is from the early 15th century, in the Sufi monasteries of Yemen, spreading soon to Mecca and Cairo. By the 16th century, it had reached the rest of the Middle East, South India (Coorg), Persia, Turkey, Horn of Africa,

first attested in 1952. The term "coffee pot" dates from 1705. According to legend, ancestors of today's Oromo people in a region of Kaffa in Ethiopia were believed to have been the first to recognize the energizing effect of the coffee plant. However, there is no direct evidence that has been found earlier than the 15th century indicating where in Africa coffee first grew or who among the native populations might have used it as a stimulant. The story of Kaldi, the 9th-century Ethiopian goatherd who discovered coffee when he noticed how excited his goats became after eating the beans

to have taken place, it is highly likely to be apocryphal. The earliest credible evidence of either coffee drinking or knowledge of the coffee tree appears in the middle of the 15th century, in Yemen's Sufi monasteries. Coffee beans were first exported from Ethiopia to Yemen. Yemeni traders brought coffee back to their homeland and began to cultivate the bean. The word "qahwa" originally meant wine, and Sufis in Yemen used the beverage as an aid to concentration and as a kind of spiritual intoxication when they chanted the name of God. Two fibers made of proteins are silk and wool. Silk is characterized by its high content of amino acids such as alanine, glycine, and serine, which contribute to its structural integrity through hydrogen bonding (origin text). Wool, on the other hand, is highlighted as an important model of animal fibers (origin text).

and fiber models. “Silk” fibers are characterized by its relatively high content of alanine, glycine, and serine; these make up over 80% of the protein residue. In order to give sufficient cohesion to resist flow, these protein chains form a tight fit over a large area. The proximity of the chains allows for firm hydrogen bonding to occur along the peptide bonds of the chain backbone. Although hydrogen bonds are relatively weak non-covalent interaction, the sheer quantity of them increases their overall effectiveness in maintaining the structure. It serves as a storage and concentration site for bile, which is produced by the liver and released into the small intestine to aid in the digestion of fats (Gallbladder In vertebrates, the gallbladder is a small hollow organ where bile is stored and concentrated before it is released into the small intestine. Gallbladder In vertebrates, the gallbladder is a small hollow organ where bile is stored and concentrated before it is released into the small intestine. In humans, the pear-shaped gallbladder lies beneath the liver, although the structure and position of the gallbladder can vary significantly among animal species. It receives and stores bile, produced by the liver, via the common hepatic duct and releases it via the common bile duct into the duodenum, where the bile helps in the digestion of fats. at the prime meridian and heading eastward, the Tropic of Cancer passes through the following countries and territories: Excluding cooler highland regions in China, the climate at the Tropic of Cancer is generally hot and dry except for easterly coastal areas where orographic rainfall can be very heavy, in some places reaching annually. Most regions on the Tropic of Cancer experience two distinct seasons: an extremely hot summer with temperatures often reaching and a warm winter with maxima around . Much land on or near the Tropic of Cancer is part of the Sahara Desert, while to the east the

climate is torrid monsoonal with a short wet season from June to September and very little rainfall for the rest of the year. The highest mountain on or adjacent to the Tropic of Cancer is Yushan in Taiwan; though it had glaciers descending as low as during the Last Glacial Maximum, none survive and at present no glaciers exist within of the Tropic of Cancer; the nearest currently surviving are the Minyong and Baishui in the Himalayas to the north and on Iztaccíhuatl to the south. Tropic of Cancer The Tropic of Cancer, which is also referred to as the Northern Tropic, is the most northerly circle of latitude on Earth at which the Sun can be directly overhead. This occurs on the June solstice, when the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun to its maximum extent. It is currently north of the Equator. Its Southern Hemisphere counterpart, marking the most southerly position at which the Sun can be directly overhead, is the Tropic of Capricorn. The plants produced in Narora, Kakrapar, and Tarapur include various horticultural and agricultural crops. Additionally, vegetables like tomato, cabbage, cauliflower, snake gourd, pumpkin, okra, corn, cucumber, beans, potato, carrot, and radish are cultivated in parts of the district. Spice cultivation is also significant, with crops like chili pepper, coriander, ginger, and turmeric being grown (document reference).

Kewra plant is dioecious, with male and female flowers produced on different plants. In Sanskrit, the plant is called Ketaki. The male plants are called 'Ketaki Viphala', and the female plants and called 'Swarana Ketaki'. Only the flowers of the male plant are harvested to extract the floral bouquet to produce kewra. The flower's bouquet is sweet, similar to rose flowers, with also some fruity notes. The plants flower three times a year (Summer, Monsoon, and Winter).
